section.name: About this Guide
section.p: The OpenEdge User Guide is intended to help developers get acquainted with the OpenEdge Modules framework. If you have any suggestions or comments please feel free to post them to the list.

section.name: Overview
section.p: The OpenEdge module framework provides for an easy to use lightweight container for components and Jobs.

Key features are:
Lightweight. You can use it in the environment you want (J2EE/ standard) and the internals of the framework are not too difficult to understand as it's aims are not sky-high (it is not intended to be the mother of all frameworks).
Easy to use. You will be up and running in less than an hour.
Flexible. It is relatively easy to plugin your own types and commands and behaviour that goes with them
Non (too) intrusive. Allthough for specific behaviour you have to implement specific interfaces, you do not have to implement any interface at all for your components. The lately very populair pattern IoC (Inversion of Control) applies to parts of this framework.
Wraps the excellent J2EE-ready sceduling framework 'Quartz' (see their website). With Quartz you have the power of a mature, production ready sceduler. OpenEdge Modules facilitates in easy configuration of Jobs and Triggers, and starts the sceduler for you, but does this in the least intrusive manner possible. You can write jobs as usual for Quartz and the only thing you have to do is configuring them (which you otherwise have to do programmatically).
